title: LNG market at mercy of headline-driven volatility – analysts
subtitle: (Montel) Global LNG markets are seeing increased volatility, with well-supplied players sitting it out and more exposed ones tracking sentiment around diplomatic efforts to end the war in Ukraine, analysts told Montel on Monday.
body:
Prices of the liquid fuel track those on European gas hubs, which last week plunged and then rose sharply on news around European plans to ease storage targets and expectations surrounding talks aimed at ending the war in Ukraine.
However, Friday’s globally broadcast spat between the US and Ukrainian presidents further cemented the sentiment-driven dynamics, analysts said.
“The market is back in headline trading mode, as last week’s selloff on news that the EU might relax storage targets was overshadowed by [the] deterioration of progress on a peace deal,” Rabobank energy strategist Florence Schmit told Montel.
“Geopolitics is driving the TTF jump this morning, as a return [of] Russian flows still seems a long way off after Friday’s show at the White House,” she added.
The benchmark front-month contract eased from earlier gains and was last seen up 3% to EUR 45.70/MWh.
Sitting it outGlobal LNG markets are therefore set to be driven by short-term requirements to cover portfolios, more than fundamentals, analysts agreed.
Asian buyers “will sit it out as long as they can” amid expectations of lower demand and prices this summer, said Schmit.
However, it will depend on exposure, noted Lu Ming Pang, senior gas and LNG Asia Pacific analyst at Rystad Energy.
“All LNG players are going to have to optimise on all the positions that they have built… to eke out as much value as possible, so [it will vary depending] on the player’s existing portfolio,” he told Montel.
Those with a long position “can afford to wait if they have already secured enough long-term volumes”, leaving less “to the whims of the spot markets”, said Pang.
However, those “looking to capitalise on short-term gains via spot deals will be following Russia-Ukraine relations very closely”, as a ceasefire agreement would “increase the chances of resumed flows through Ukraine, which would relax global gas and LNG prices”, he said.
In the meantime, prices will continue to rise and fall with sentiment and speculation, Pang said, and “players that require those cargoes urgently will still need to come into the market”.
Asian LNG imports plunged by 16% on the month in February, and by 9% on the year, to 20.3m tonnes.
